page.title: 09Bartholomew Gosnold/Godspeed
page.content: His family home was Otley Hall and he was described by Cpt John Smith as the prime mover of Jamestown, the first successful English settlement in America. In 1571 he went to Cambridge and then into law in London. The Earl of Southampton became his patron and financed his voyage to America in 1602. He named Cape Cod on this voyage, and Martha's Vineyard after his daughter who had died, aged 2, just before his departure. Various expeditions of his were planned and discussed in Otley Hall. After 4years of planning, 5 months of perilous voyaging, Bartholomew was dead within weeks of arrival, of a fever. And within a few years his family sank with the Royalist cause.
